factsheet.heading: Location
paragraphs: The Experimental Weave Lab (TEWL) is housed in a former church hall right in the heart of the City of London. This unique location is rich in history, heritage and a little mystique! The church hall we are located in, St.Olave's Parish Hall, is owned by The Clothworkers' Company, who have generously loaned us the use of the hall for our 6-month artist residency programme.
The church hall had been unused for a number of years prior to TEWL moving in. Adjacent to the hall is the original church's tower and crypt built in the 1300s.

This will be the last opportunity for the public to access the space as it is now. In 2023, the entire site (minus the listed church tower & crypt) will be knocked down and a new skyscraper, winter garden and public plaza will be built over the course of 5 years.

factsheet.heading: Innovation
paragraphs: The Experimental Weave Lab (TEWL) is the City of London's first contemporary, professional season of events relating to weaving. On a daily basis, TEWL is run as a studio housing a  series of professional artist and designer residencies across a 6 month programme. Every month a new artist or designer joins our studio with the sole intention of creating experimental woven work.

During our opening for Open House London, we will be holding a work in progress exhibition of all the work created during our residency programme. You will also be able to see live weaving and you will be able to meet some of the artists and designers involved in TEWL.

factsheet.heading: Textiles - what the City of London was founded on
paragraphs: Whilst TEWL has bought contemporary weaving to the City of London, the creation of textiles in the City is nothing new. The City has a rich history of textile production - everything from passementerie weaving, cloth tentering, textile finishing and import and export of materials, yarns and textiles.
